comments.commentBody: As long as the media, and that includes the Times, covers Trump he is not going away. The media give oxygen to the Trump fire breathing act all day long. When I pick up my Times and see NO mention of Trump that day I will smile. But I am really not expecting to see that day anytime soon.

replies.commentBody:
@Douglas Ritter 

"And it is scary that Mr. Trump has been trying to take democracy down with him as he attempts to sell his latest scheme. "

With Tweets attacking democracy, he revives it!
Trump has exposed democracy weaknesses, Biden can fix.

(Recall Murphy's Law: If anything can go wrong, it will)

A new democracy wave may, now be coming, with Biden.
"Democracy is coming to the USA" (Leonard Cohen song)

Can the Times  write about the idea of a democracy wave?
"Democracy is coming to the USA"

@Douglas Ritter 
I respectfully disagree - I think most of the media will ignore him unless he is newsworthy- not just bloviating.

@Douglas Ritter These things always boil down to the money - follow it and it will give you the correct way to look at the situation. The "Fake News Media" got tremendously rich off of Trump - they would have to disappear too - not sure if that is going to happen - just sayin'.

comments.commentBody:
I don't know about the rest of you folks, but I am really looking forward to that day that we will wake up to find Zero news awaiting us relating to Donald Trump.
It will feel like a beautiful peaceful, sunny, Sunday morning in springtime.
The only tweets will be from the real birds outside the window.
Amen...

replies.commentBody:
@JimmyCanuck 

And noble public servants will again populate the executive branch.  Someone in AZ brought up the idea of Jeff Flake recruited--  a gentleman statesman.

But Trump will still terrorize to whatever degree, via his base, because of the rewards he brings himself that way.  And that will put a damper on what congress gets done.

The challenge to get at least one more blue senate seat is high.  Grassroots GA groups working toward a win are listed at movement.vote.  Heroes!

@JimmyCanuck 
Except that I will gladly follow the progress of his legal problems in New York.

@JimmyCanuck Indeed... and do you remember your last holidays in the mountains, the woods or wherever, when you indulged in listening to the birds' tweets instead of other, more repugnant, ones? When all you did is walk or hike in the beautiful silence.... and how boring it became after one, two or three weeks (assuming you stayed long enough)?

How long might the majority of TV viewers 'enjoy' in depths analysis of plus and minus for the job market of a trade deal, negotiated by the new administration?
Or the long time consequences on CO2 levels of a new technical standard for internal combustion engines discussed by EPA?
Or the prospects of new rounds of international talks on anti nuclear proliferation?

The current relief, experienced by so many, will quickly fade. The hunger for the next outrageous Twitter remark by those disgusting (fill in your political opponents) just to have something you can indignantly discuss with your like minded friends will soon come back.

Human nature is what it is, and if this makes me a misanthrope, than so be it.

comments.commentBody:
I believe and hope that Ms Swisher is wrong. Not that I disagree with her analysis. However, if Twitter has any corporate integrity, it will cancel Donald Trump's account at 12:01pm January 20th.

Trump has broken Twitter's rules any number of times but has been forgiven because he's the president and newsworthy. Once he's no longer the president, that protection should no longer apply. Let's see how this plays out.

replies.commentBody: @John Lister Hi John. I wholeheartedly agree. In a future where the tables have turned completely, it will be wonderful for every corporation and organization to be able to arbitrarily adjust standards of free expression and speech, including NYT comments. Ownership, like leadership, evolves and changes over time. New Brunswick is beautiful, no?

@viktor64 

Viktor,

I thought "conservatives" are for limited government, private rights, non-interference of the government in free enterprise, etc.

If Trump wants freedom of expression, he can go freely express himself anywhere he wants including the sidewalk. 

A private for-profit entity with stated user policy, which he signed on to, has the right to implement those rights. 

"Conservatives" seems to stick to their principles only when they are convenient.
Twitter needs to allow non-Twitter users to report violations of its Terms of Service.

comments.commentBody: As soon as Trump leaves office, Twitter should strictly apply the same standards of conduct to him as it does to everyone else.  No more exemption because of his status as a “world leader”.

replies.commentBody:
@JB 
Don't expect Twitter (or any other social media company) to ever act in public interest.  They will do whatever is best for their bottomline in the short term.

@JB  Jack Dorsey said today that they will do just that, treat Trump as a private citizen subject to normal rules. But Trump may have an end run: declare himself a candidate for president in 2024. Then we’ll see how Twitter treats him as a political figure.

comments.commentBody: I look forward to the end of Trump's tweets almost as much as I look forward to the end of newspaper articles about Trump's tweets, almost as much as I look forward to the end of newspaper articles about Trump.

replies.commentBody:
@Todd I was just writing an email to MY base: my family and friends with whom I have developed tighter bonds since this twin nightmare of Covid and Trump have enveloped us like malevolent serpents; I was reading something about how the cod have disappeared from our oceans almost without notice and now that's going on twenty *years* . . . and I wrote, just the other day, almost as a sudden realization, almost as if blinders were pulled off: "Who talks about this (the cod)? Who writes about this? All they write about is DONALD TRUMP . . . while the oceans empty and grow silent and all the life that depends on them disappears and grow silent and all we hear is DONALD TRUMP, DONALD TRUMP, DONALD TRUMP . . . "

Well, the day is going to dawn—it seems unimaginable at the moment, but it is coming, it really is—that the first thing we think about upon waking is *not* going to be (all caps) DONALD TRUMP. And that day, mark my words, is going to be a very, VERY bigly day.

comments.commentBody:
Trump will probably fade as a force on social media as he and his followers mutually lose interest.  The issue is the next would-be Trump, and there assuredly will be one.  

Trump was elected partially because he got nonstop free coverage from networks and media who recognized his entertainment value.  As Moonves observed he wasn't good for the country but he sure was good for CBS and others.

So when the next wannabe cult leader/strongman/outrage peddler arrives on the scene, will we have learned anything or will it be business as usual again?

replies.commentBody: @Pat - It won't be very long before Jr. ascends to claim the mantle, with daddy's blessing or not.

@Pat 
Business as usual, is my guess.

comments.commentBody:
Ms. Swisher writes, "Which is why it is not a stretch to imagine Trump acolytes will get weary of the president’s antics when they are no longer as much fun. And they will tire of them, too, because everyone eventually tires of online acts. Mr. Trump resembles a hot app or viral video or popular video game or cool start-up that can suddenly go ice-cold."

Now, I don't know where Ms. Swisher lives, but I'm going to hazard a guess that she doesn't live among too many Trump voters.

The notion that his voters will tire and simply move on is wishful thinking. As long as he has even the most remote possibility of running again in 2024, his voters will stay by him.

Again, the vast majority of this 70+ million people believe the election was "stolen" from Trump. They will continue to literally hang onto his every word, whether it be on Twitter or elsewhere. And even if Twitter does ban Trump at some point (which I doubt), there are always any number of other social media outlets, and cable outlets where he can continue to spew his garbage, to the joy of his cult-like following.

No, Trump's voters had a taste of power, and they're not going to let go of it so easily. The most grossly unfit man ever to hold the office gave them the version of America they wanted. If they were going to have tired of Trump, they would have done so long ago.

Regardless of Twitter, Trump remains and threat, and his voters remain a threat. And the rest of us need to remain vigilant.

replies.commentBody:
@Orion Clemens 
I'm guessing only the bottom feeding 40% actually believe the election was stolen.  The fact that only 11,000 or so showed up for the mega rally last Saturday says a lot about his support.  Imagine if trump had succeeded in overturning the election--I'm guessing there would be millions who would flood the streets--myself being one of them.

@Orion Clemens -

You say Trump's voters had a taste of power.  Well, we Obama voters had a taste of power before.  And we liked it then, and now have gotten it back.  We will do everything to make sure we don't lost our power to unworthy candidates.

@Orion Clemens As someone who does live among Trump voters, I think it's a toss-up. The vast majority (at least here) get their "news" from one place and one place only: what comes across their Facebook pages (to be fair, this is also true of the leftists here; I worked with one 20-something Dem who hated Trump, yet refused to vote this year because he was convinced by an edited photo on Facebook of the same execrable, unrepeatable lie about Joe Biden I've heard repeated dozens of times by Trump voters). They never read a newspaper or watch a news program (even Fox). So really, I think it all comes down to whether or not time and algorithmic changes blunt his ever-presence on that particular platform.

comments.commentBody: A new day is dawning in America, inauguration day January 2021. While I did not vote for Trump in 2016, I accepted the results of the election, hoping that he would be presidential and professional. He was neither, in my opinion. At this point, I would like Trump to be quiet, stop twittering, go golfing every day. I don't care about his taxes at all. I am looking forward to his children going back to whatever their lives are and never to be heard from again. He had his four years to MAGA, but he failed in my opinion. The results of his reign are unacceptable. I am looking forward to the leadership of Joe Biden and Kamala Harris.

replies.commentBody:
@Ted 
   I would love to never see his face again.  Unfortunately, that shouldn’t happen.  America can’t let his illegality slide.

@Ted 
With Joe Biden and Kamala Harris in the White House, MAGA has succeeded beyond its dreams.
@Ted Yes!  I can't wait until the day Trump and his enablers leave the White House for good!  Really, really looking forward to it!!  Very soon!!

comments.commentBody: Right on.  But the more important things is to hold him accountable (and Fox News etc...) for nearly a quarter million deaths by using his office to misinform a vulnerable populous.  Additionally, a Truth and Reconciliation Commission needs to be established to mourn the tragedy of what we have lost under his leadership.  It is not enough for him to go away.  He must be held accountable.

replies.commentBody:
Thank you for saying that. I have wondered if anyone else has characterized these cases and deaths as crimes against humanity. I know there have been unavoidable deaths worldwide, especially in the early days of COVID-19, but the Trump administration’s outright refusal to provide meaningful federal leadership in the pandemic and instead substituting it with a transactional approach that is closer to hostage taking, plus the politicization of mask-wearing and other mitigation measures, have undoubtedly resulted in higher case counts and deaths. Where is the accountability for this utterly inhumane, morally vacuous behaviour? 

The cases from SDNY pale in comparison. This requires The Hague.
@EGD If Cuomo was informed of what Trum knew in January, then he might have been able to take the proper precautions and prevent thousands of deaths.

comments.commentBody: The difference between Trump's time in office and when he's finally out of office is that the media will no longer air his tweets. No one will care.  At the beginning of his term it was said that what he says in a tweet is policy and that's been true whether it's firing people via a tweet or telling the world what policies he's enacting. No one will care anymore or have to report it.  He can tweet all he wants through his Twitter account but we don't have to hear about it.

replies.commentBody: @carolinagirl  And Biden will do "presidenting" the right way, and not use the power of tweets to rule. It will be nice to go back to the old-fashioned way of doing things.

@carolinagirl 
The media will continue to report on him if it makes money. So I recommend you ignore any article about trump's tweets, and ignore as many as possible about him in general.
The 73 million people who voted for Trump watch Fox News, and yes, Fox News will keep reporting about Trump. Constantly. So the idea that “No one cares” is, unfortunately, not really true.

comments.commentBody: Twitter, Facebook, instagram, whatever. They all have our democracy's blood on their hands, as do the millions of Americans that criticize them and yet remain just as tethered to their accounts as those they disagree with. Delete Facebook. Delete Twitter. Free yourself from the toxic, yet illusory shackles of social media. You'll thank yourself in the end.

replies.commentBody:
@Jordan -
It will be a long time until we get someone like Donald Trump again. There's no show in our fragmented TV culture like the Apprentice to capture public interest.  And then to leverage that celebrity into the presidency was a fluke that only a lucky Donald got to experience.  I doubt if a Marvel Comic hero is going to capture the general public's interest, at least not for a long time.

@Jordan Done and done the minute it became clear four years ago the extent to which social media aided in the installation of the Orange Menace.
I have absolutely no regrets.

@Jordan

I would love, love, love to delete Facebook! In fact, I've never had an account-- but postings by my husband's Facebook "friends" have found my phone. Is there any way to limit Facebook posts to grandchildren and puppies? There must be a market for that!

comments.commentBody:
Swisher makes the same mistake that so many others have made in this tin pot president's cult of personality. Maybe it is easier to focus on the bright shiny object, but the elephant in the room is really Trump supporters.

Who are Trump's supporters, and why are there so many of them? Why are reporters so unwilling to delve into the proto-campaign of Trump promoting the Birther Myth, a Big Lie with no equal in modern American politics?

The Birther Myth gathered a base of racist Neo-Confederates around Trump that he could then use to batter down all of the other Republican presidential candidates. Impressively, only Putin and the Kremlin seemed to understand that this could really work. 

The heart of the matter is that we have a core group in the Evangelical Party that can dictate how their false front Republicans will speak and act. 

The Evangelical Party, formed in 1845 by the Southern Baptists, is still fighting the Civil War now rebranded as the Culture War. 

And they are winnihg that war.

replies.commentBody:
@UTBG 
It only seems like they are winning the war, due to our inadequate system of checks and balances and laws.  If people put the senate in democrat's hands, there will be plenty of swift legislation that will be aimed at getting ready of various loopholes that Moscow Mitch and DJT have exposed.
@indisk a handful of milquetoast senators will prevent any decisive moves.  And the senate has not flipped in any case and appears unlikely to do so.
@UTBG Just keep in mind that Trump LOST the popular vote by more than 5 million ballots.  And do not forget that he lost the popular vote in 2016.  Time to get rid of the electoral college.

comments.commentBody:
I expect that President Biden will communicate openly, honestly and frequently with the American people, but I would prefer it to  be never by tweet. 

TV, radio, newspapers. U.S. mail and pony express are O.K.

replies.commentBody: @A. Stanton I SO agree with you on this. I don't use Twitter, but millions do so I suppose there is some utility to it for politicians. If Joe Biden and Kamala Harris used it to promote policy or events, that would be fine. But it should not be used to attack opponents, make or announce policy and especially not to fire staff members. That is just childish and sick.

comments.commentBody:
The sad truth is that Trump's followers have had every opportunity to see through is falsehoods, and have chosen not to do so.

Surely, they are aware that Covid didn't disappear as Trump repeatedly said it would?

Surely, Mexico hasn't yet paid for the wall?

I wish I could agree that Trump has lost its hold, but I fear that the loyalty of his followers is more religious than rational.

replies.commentBody: @Josh Hill Agreed. Rationality seems to be the furthest thing from their minds . . .

@Josh Hill People think it's easier to be loyal than to be smart, but in this instance, their loyalty will hurt them badly. Some loyals - Herman Cain, for example - have already paid with their lives.
The hardest thing they'll have to do, eventually, is admit they were conned. Someone should start a support group.

@Josh Hill "... I fear that the loyalty of his followers is more religious than rational."

Right you are! There is a word for his followers: zealots. Take a look through history to find clues as to where this road may lead.

comments.commentBody:
The end of Trump's reign as president and his tweets can't come soon enough.  Trump, his administration, congressional Republicans and evangelicals have tried their best to make dishonesty and corruption, which permeate almost every aspect of these groups, acceptable additions to their "family values."  

It is my hope that Joe Biden is able to again establish that honesty and integrity matter.

I have always believed that Trump ends like Lonesome Roads, Andy Griffith's character in A Face in the Crowd; screaming out a window with nobody listening. I believe that Trump will maintain a certain allure to a small faction of deplorables. He may even run for reelection in 2024, ultimately failing to get the nomination and then running as an independent. He will become older and more pathetic. He will finally fade away like Father Coughlin and Joseph McCarthy. Just another right wing has been that Americans will read about in history books.
What goes around, comes around.  Trump will soon learn that nobody listens when it doesn't matter.  He will soon have so many blocks, labels against, that his "fan" base will go elsewhere.

replies.commentBody:
@ME 

Exactly correct.  It's one thing when the POTUS tweets outrageous, provocative things but now that Trump is the digital equivalent of an old man yelling at squirrels it just doesn't have the same impact.

comments.commentBody:
Trump's behavior right now is sublimely poetic. 

Each day, Trump makes it more clear he is a delusional sore loser unwilling to face reality. 

It is the perfect send-off for a sociopath.

replies.commentBody: @Civic Samurai Too bad he still has so much power and no one to tell him NO, DON'T DO THAT!
Awesome thought and well said. Thank you for expressing what we all want to shout!

comments.commentBody:
Kara, I really hope Trump goes away from Twitter. He is a “Shock Jock” provocateur and we are all tired of him. 

Long time ago, visionary Canadian media philosopher Marshall McLuhan predicted about the “Post Literate Society” with the advent of multimedia technology. With social media platforms like Twitter, Facebook etc, the “Post Literate Society” is here now: People don’t “read and reflect” anymore, people just “react” to Twitter feeds. 

Twitter co founder Ev Williams regretted inventing Twitter that may have led to Donald Trump’s controversial presidential victory. 

Lastly, one more of McLuhan’s predictions also became true: “Medium is the Medium”. In other words, the medium is more important than the message. For example, Trump’s early morning tweets tend to carry more significance albeit his messages frequently tend to be malapropism oriented and syntactically challenged. 

I’m sick of Trump’s tweets - I need normalcy in my life.

replies.commentBody: @RCS Post literate is a polite way of putting it. Most people these days will take the opinions of talking heads on just about any subject, rather than do the hard work of seeking objective sources of information for their own edification. The result is normally such a shallow understanding of subject matter that one couldn't possibly explain it to them in a social media format.

@RCS 
I've studied neuroscience quite a bit and I'm convinced that negative news feeds (whether in the form of TV, tweets or posts) create stress, which in turn creates inflammation, which in turn is the root cause of many diseases and makes us more apt to use our mid-brain than our pre-frontal cortex. 

trump gives off so many toxic vibes that I have made it a personal policy to never hear him speak or see him move. Just taking in his facial expressions and tone of voice too often can be harmful. 

And Twitter I have happily avoided. I've dabbled in FB but most of these things are more distressing than connecting.

@RCS 

Good post. Just a little typo:  McLuhan actually said “the medium is the message”.

comments.commentBody:
Twitter has yet to offer a rational explanation of how Trump has been able to (mis)use its platform for this long.

Yes, Trump will be a private citizen on 1/20/20, and therefore subject to the Twitter rules of any other private citizen. But it's not as if he's been Tweeting his venom on the official @WhiteHouse account. He's been using his personal @realDonaldTrump account from day one throughout his time in office. That account, by virtue of being a personal account, should have been subject to the rules of any private user's account all along.

replies.commentBody: @D Price Excellent point.  It was his private account and should not have been given any privileged status.
Exactly! Well put D Price

comments.commentBody:
You do realise that >73 million Americans voted for him don't you? Yes, it is great they will no longer have the dog-whistler in chief in the White House, but what makes you think they're just going to fade away into oblivion or accept that he lost and move on? He's certainly not going anywhere...other than out of the White House...eventually.
Your assertion that "he will continue to rage to an ever emptier room until his rants meld into louder noise" sounds at best wishful thinking and at worst woefully naive

replies.commentBody:
@Stoopblogg 
I have to reluctantly agree with you.   73 million are a lot of people. Many of us would hope that he would have a drastically smaller audience or "base", but as the comment reflects , it is "wishful thinking."

@Stoopblogg   73 Million voted against the democrats, not necessarily for Trump.  Once he is out the former will rally around the next GOP hopeful (Paul Ryan comes to mind).  Trump has forever tainted anyone from his family to aspiring to National Office again (maybe they could win a Florida election for something)

@Stoopblogg 


2 words.   Sarah Palin

comments.commentBody: Perhaps a tax investigation will get rid of him for good. It was only tax evasion that made it possible to judge and convict Al Capone. We may hope the same for Trump.

replies.commentBody: @Jean-Jacques   Yes.  God may be slow but He always shows up on time.

comments.commentBody: Well, in any case he's no longer going to be able to use Twitter to fire cabinet members or conduct foreign policy.  That has to be an improvement.

replies.commentBody: @Stan Sutton This was illegal when he did it.  Not sure why people and the media bought into the lie that the president is above the law.

comments.commentBody: I disagree.  Over 70 million people voted for Trump.  He craves attention and is a master at getting it.  I think he’ll be a very vocal online critic of everything Biden does. He won’t get presidential-level attention but he’ll still be a force to reckon with. I hope he goes away but I think it’s a fantasy to expect it. I hope I’m wrong.

replies.commentBody:
@Ker

But Twitter will hv the power to pull his tweets totally down (no more silly stickers), suspend or even terminate his account. 
I think the media will eventually slow down on reporting on him.  
He’s also 74.  He will become irrelevant, eventually.  
His kids will try to carry the torch, and as bad as they are, they don’t hold a candle to dear old dad.

@Ker 
Maybe.  But think about all the other big name, big mouths that had their moment in the sun and then were gone. (anybody spend any time thinking about Jimmy Swaggart these days?)    How many people actually paid much attention to trump after The Apprentice was over and before he was president?    He is going to go back to stand in front of a very small audience.  If nothing else, they are going to get tired of being hounded for money.

@Ker I think the media will determine he is like the boy who cried WOLF, and soon lose interest, while his base will get bored with him, unless he can come up with a new message. Every fad eventually passes. I think we havent heard from him because he hasnt been able to come up with a new wheeze to get attention or take peoples minds off the election. It looks like he was maybe thinking Iran, but he is chicken when it comes to actual war, and was easily talked out of it. He aint no general....and he knows it. He prefers stealth bombing on home territory.

comments.commentBody: You are totally missing the point. Celebrate the wand! Thank goodness for his Tweeting Power! That is what made us aware of his insanity.

replies.commentBody: @James how's that awareness working for USA James?
